title.narrative: Support Ministry of Health Preparedness to Respond to COVID-19

description.narrative: Activity 1- International Medical Corps will set up screening room for triage and isolation of patients at the hospitals in Bria, Bambari and Birao. screening and isolation units installed. No patients tested positive during the reporting period. last positive case was in Bria in June 2020. Activity 2: Ensure case management through a 20-bed establishment in the hospitals of Bria, Bambari and Birao. Installation of tents with 20 beds in Bria and 8 beds in Birao. Activity 3: Purchase and supply pharmaceutical products, medical supplies, including PPE, medical equipment and IPC supplies for the three hospitals of Bria, Bambari and Birao and MSF France. international order for drugs, supplies and medical equipment launched in September and in November 2020.This was due to the fact that after the project was approved no cases were recorded in the country therefore IMC was considering modifying the requests according to the situation on the ground. Part of this order will be a donation to MSF-France in Bria. Activity 4: Provide MHPSS services to staff, patients and community members, including telephone counseling, Psychosocial support to frontline workers, patients and their families. MHPSs team were available to offer services to patients who have been screened. Activity 5: Strengthen the installation of additional hand washing stations in the health establishment and waste management (according to the COVID-19 protocol). Each isolation site is equipped with safe environmental hygiene measures. Activity 6: Recruit human resources for the project. IMC launched recruitment of staff for the project, but delayed due to shortage of health care personnel like Medical doctors. Activity 7: Transport of supplies to the field. PPE received in country was transported in September 2020. Output 2 - Activity 1: International Medical Corps UK will use the existing Community Health Workers (CHWs) to conduct community and household level awareness on COVID-19 such as dispelling myths, and communication on preventive measures, symptoms and what to do if ill. CHWs were trained and provided with masks for door-to-door visits to protect them. IEC materials on COVID-19 messages were distributed to them to raise awareness and emphasize to recognize the symptoms of COVID-19. Activity 2: Involve CHWs to conduct community-based surveillance and patients’ referral’s, Weekly report, is shared during the meeting of the multisectoral prefectural committee responsible for locally coordinating the response to COVID 19 in each site before being sent to the MOH.

title.narrative: To support community impacted by Covid in 5 districts of MP

description.narrative: Overall intervention to benefit 1600 Covid impacted HH, migrants, single women headed, PWD and household without earnings. Providing nutri mix food to children help them to recover severe malnutrition. Setting up Covid WASH stations and surveillance help in containment of disease and to maintain hygiene among the community. Linkages between hospitals and PRI to benefit the community. 150 volunteers to work within the community help to monitor the Covid spread and to conduct awareness on covid related behaviour and vaccination. Distribution of hygiene kits including masks and sanitizer help in providing protection.

The project intervention will be in 5 districts of Madhya Pradesh. They are Sagar, Betul, Mandla, Sehore and Khandwa where the targeted community belongs to indigenous tribal community. The project to be implemented in 90 villages and 150 community volunteers to work as front line warriors. Activity includes a) capacity building of volunteers and community on covid appropriate behaviour and vaccination b) installation of community wash stations per village c) distribution of dry ration to 1600 beneficiaries d) hygiene kits including sanitary pads to 2000 beneficiaries e) vulnerable HH to be identified through rapid survey f) establishing linkage with hospitals, PRIs and health professional to support community access to treatment.

title.narrative: Communities at the Centre: Enabling First Line Emergency Responses in Myanmar

description.narrative: Protracted conflicts require a new, women-led approach to shift power to local populations so they can move from short-term humanitarian ways of working to integrated approaches involving localisation, capacity building, humanitarian interventions, development and security, with the aim to leave no one behind. This action is designed to equip local civil society organisations (CSOs) and community-based front-line emergency actors and self-help groups (CBOs) with the resources to prepare and respond to crises. In the Mrauk-U and Buthidaung townships of Rakhine State, this action will enable local communities to design responsible, adaptable and accountable responses to crises – community- and women-led responses as dynamic and incisive as the conflict-induced crises and natural disasters are destabilising and unpredictable. This unpredictabulity is compunded by the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic which will further affect the access to services and communities. This action has three components: 1) Local actors’ skills, capacities and knowledge are enhanced to lead responsibly managed, women-led first-line emergency responses; 2) Township contingency and response plans based on locally-led risk analysis established; and 3) Front Line Emer

This action has three components: 1) Local actors’ skills, capacities and knowledge are enhanced to lead responsibly managed, women-led first-line emergency responses; 2) Township contingency and response plans based on locally-led risk analysis established; and 3) Front Line Emergency Response system designed and implemented. Each component increases opportunities for local actors to lead the design and implementation of community- and women-led humanitarian mechanisms. In total, 33.114 IDPs and crisis-affected people, 50 key stakeholders (local authorities, private sector, religious entities, community groups) and 42 local organizations providing front line emergency responses in the targeted townships will benefit from this action: empowering communities, designing local responses, strengthening collective action and tackling power imbalances, thus laying the foundations for resilience against future crises.

title.narrative: Supporting Recovery,Protection & Livelihoods of the Marginalised,Displaced & Returnees-Nigeria AA

description.narrative: The activities are designed to reach the target population using a well-structured detailed and sequenced implementation plans that captures specific activities and timelines. In 7 days, stakeholders identification and engagement would have been concludeed with identification of CRM focal persons whiloe the rapid assessment to determine beneficiaries of NFIs and cash will be underway. The intervention will be led by local partners with already existing volunteer structures across communities who will serve as enumerators for rapid assessment and stakeholder engagement activities to be coordinated with government agencies, traditional institutions and faith based organizations that will be used for information communication and dissemination, risk communication and community engagement activities, distribution exercises and awareness creation, community and social mobilization officers will be adopted from the for mass awareness and sensitization activities at the community level.

The project will respond to WASH, Cash, Health, Protection and Disaster Risk Reduction (DRR) and NFIs. The response will reach beneficiaries experiencing health emergencies including Covid 19 and Yellow fever which are both WASH related emergencies to be addressed through an integrated risk communication and community engagements, local and mainstream approaches to WASH to maximize community participation and sustainability. Households and health facilities will be supported with Covid 19 WASH kits to strengthen infection prevention control (IPC) for Covid 19 to reduce community and facility transmission. WASH activities will mainstream yellow fever specifically with the provision of mosquito nets for households and facilities and also risk communication and community engagement activities including capacity building activities and Information Education and Communication (IEC) dissemination activities through local town criers for local reach and radio jingles for posters for wider reach. The project will train community volunteers who will track false information and myths at community levels and will urgently to address this false information using various channels such as door to door sensitisations and IEC materials

title.narrative: To provide support to vulnerable community through multi purpose cash transfer in UP, Bihar and Delh

description.narrative: EFICOR is working in Delhi, UP and Bihar with the most marginalised community who are depending on daily wages for their livelihood. In this intervention the targeted community would be migrants, PWDs, single women headed HH and people with HIV and HH who lost their earning member due to Covid. Migrants from other cities are returning to villlages and their livelihood and food security is at stake. EFICOR to provide multi purpose cash transfer to the targeted community in 5 villages in Manikpur block of Chitrakoot district of Uttar Pradesh to cover 600 HH, 10 villages in Madhur block of Madhubani district of Bihar to cover 600 HH and in Delhi/NCR Krishna Colony in West Delhi to cover 550 HH. In Total EFICOR to provide direct cash benefit of INR 2000/- through bank transfer to 1750 HH ( 8750 individuals) in three States of India. All the beneficiaries to be mapped through KOBO Collect digital app and necessary documents to be collected and verified by the project staff before transferring the amount.

Multipurpose cash transfer to community provides flexibility and freedom to spend on any immediate needs. Using KOBO App to support in identified HH data are collected authentically and all documents to be uploaded into server quickly. Using Kobo collect also eliminates chances of dublicate entries and the records can be verified any time.

title.narrative: To provide support to Covid Impacted community in 2 districts of Madhya Pradesh

description.narrative: The project intervention to be done in 7 blocks, 151 villages of Shivpuri & Datia districts of Madhya Pradesh where the impact of Covid is much higher in comparison to previous year. Also these districts are bordering with States like Maharashtra with highest number of Covid cases, hence reverse migration is expected due to less testing, it may have more implication. The project activities include a) 7 model isolation centres to support 840 individuals for 5 days cycle b) mobility van support at 7 block level to help 2450 covid affected individuals to reach hospitals c) 2500 children in the age group of 1-5 years to get nutritional support d)750HH of migrants to get dry ration support and community mobilizer and isolation centres to be provided with basic medical equipment to monitor symptomatic people. 10000 people to receive masks stitched by SHGs. 15 days campaign on Covid and vaccination to benefit across the community

These districts with tribal population have no access to basic health facilities. establishment of isolation centres with leveraging medicines, oxygen and health workers support to identify covid symptom individual and to timely isolation. Nutrition mix provides malnutrition children with health benefits and mobility support ensures timely medical treatment. 750HH without access to government PDS scheme to receive support and other HH to get support in accessing free ration as announced by Government. Providing basic equipments help the volunteers to monitor the Covid spread within the village. triple layered cloth masks to protect community from Covid.

title.narrative: UTHAN- Uplifting the Poor and Needy

description.narrative:
- Improved understanding of vulnerability of individuals at the community and Municipality level. - Social Epowerment: # HHs are socially empowered through improved access to entitlements, services, social networks & meaningful participation in the development planning processes - Economic Empowerment: # of vulnerable individuals are directly economically empowered through improved income from diverse & appropriate climate smart agro based livelihood activities, off-farm activities & vocational trainings to fulfill their food & other basic needs - Safe Permanent shelter & CCA/DRR: # of vulnerable & earthquake affected individual are residing in safe permanent shelters & have effective representation in Ward & Municipality disaster preparedness processesand municipality have capacity & knowledge on climate induced disaster, its adaptation measures.
The key response activities of this project covers livelihood, food security, WASH/health & awareness as primary intervention. Distribution of food assistance/relief package, Installation of Hand washing station, PPE , disinfectant/ sanitizer, mask material support, special Food Package support for chronic disease patient & poorest people & radio PSAs are the major activities

The project will ensure that all 3416-vulnerable people are benefitted from activities, out of which 125 single women, 502 Older People, 289 PwDs, and 4065 extremely poor and food insecure people have improved awareness and access to their constitutional rights and entitlements and awared and prepared for future disaster and climate change
The response will ensure the food security of poor, people with disability, marginalized and vulnerable people through food assistance/relief package for at least 20-30 days, PPE, disinfectant, sanitizer, mask support for rural municipality will be done to secure health of medical person, FCHVs & person working in the front line, initiate some action for food production & livestock rearing which will help to recover from the covid-19 pandemic & ensure food security to some extent & broadcast 4 types of PSA from district local FMs will be aired to disseminate information on the virus.

title.narrative: Ensuring Food Security, Livelihood Support to the 2000 migrant families in Uttar Pradesh

description.narrative: Apart from livelihood support Dalit and marginalised community to be capacitated on rights and entitlements so they will be able to take raise voice with district administration. Also it is expected that the project will aim to reduce the migration along with gender discrimination and women participation will increase at village level activities. When the women generate income on her own, the gender based violence will also reduce and will give rise to social economic development of migrants particularly women.

The project will be implemented in 8 districts 60 gram panchayats of Uttar Pradesh targeting 2000 migrant families who have returned to their villages due to Covid 19 lockdown. These families have lost their livelihood in urban cities and their social economic status is very gloomy as of now. As per the Government guidelines these migrants will be provided work under NREGA along with job card and ration card. CASA will conduct a survey to assess the status of migrants with regard to social security documents and labour committee to be formed to monitor the rights & entitlements. CASA to provide dry ration consists of rice, wheatflour, oil, pulses and sanitary kits such as masks, soap and sanitary pads to last for 15 days to 2000 families. Some of the families have small agricultural land and to be provided seeds of millets, staple foods and vegetable seeds to enable them to grow on their own so that their food security will be ensured. Awareness programme on Covid 19 will also be conducted in these districts and distribution of IEC/BCC materials will be taken up.

title.narrative: PH R1: Strengthening Climate Advocacy in Asia in the time of COVID-19

description.narrative: For ACCC, within a year's time, we envision a regional civil society organization, along with its members, that is capable of ensuring the continuity of climate and disaster resilience advocacy, through innovate approaches, in government, inter-governmental, and relavant platforms in the face of COVID 19 and the new normal.

The project aims to : -strengthen capacities for climate advocacy in the time of COVID-19 where face to face engagement are no longer the norm in the short term. -support the work of ACCC members engaging in online advocacy through virtual roundtables, webinars and online campaigning. Specifically: 1)influencing the COVID 19 recovery/devt planning processes, the NDC and National adapt processes, with the purpose of strengthening movement-building, policy, and campaign on climate action in the normal. 2) providing the access to online platforms, it is the hope of ACCC that COVID-19 programs do nor further suppress movement-building and to further the right of CSOs and other stakeholders to participate in governance. 3) Supporting ACCC members gain access to inter--governmental platforms, regionally, other stakeholders and multi-lateral development banks and financial instiutions 4) ACCC will keep its commitment to the communities they work for to ensure alternative participatory and feedback mechanisms that inform the policy advocacy work.

title.narrative: Faith Action on Covid-19 Transformation in Sierra Leone

description.narrative: - Increased reach and knowledge on Covid-19 preventions and mitigation - symptoms and how to prevent it, and who is most at risk, reporting suspected cases/referrals. - Decreased social and economic impact of Covid-19 on the most vulnerable. - Increased capacity of faith actors to provide appropriate counselling and referral for victims of SGBV, stigmatization and discrimination.

CASL is proposing a limited set of interventions, to deepen gains and minimize impact on vulnerable groups in three districts - Western Rural, Bo and Pujehun, building on its Code 1 and earlier CA Appeal funding investments with its partner RADA who will work closely with inter-faith leaders through the Side-by-Side movement to scale messaging, support vulnerable groups and ensure local capacity to sustain engagements on Covid-19 and Sexual and Gender Based Violence. CASL will weave these interventions with existing support to earlier initiatives with inter-faith groups, using RADA's experience working with inter-faith leaders to ensure engagements at the district, chiefdom and community levels. The Side-by-Side movement had earlier been supported to disseminate Covid-19 messages and to support with handwashing materials in the early stages of the pandemic. This support will seek to strengthen these actions and to reach beyond Freetown to the provinces. RADA has been involved with local faith leaders in dissemination of Covid-19 prevention messages in the south of the country, buiding capacity of community members and distributing handwashing kits including soap to 20 rural communities

title.narrative: IOPT / PARC West Bank: Covid-19 Response

description.narrative: Food production is increased and food security improved in the two villages for 3,200 people. These people will also have increased resilience and capacity to deal with the long-term shocks, political and health related.

This project addresses COVID-19 in the Jordan Valley OPT, responding to the immediate need to minimise the spread of the virus as well as the impact of lockdown and economic consequences thereof. It also creates a sustainable long-term solution for community resilience and food security, both of which are areas of the humanitarian country plan that are currently not well funded. Crucially, this deals with the long-term issues facing communities in OPT, the most prevalent at the moment being threatened annexation.
Marj - Na'jaa and Al-Zbiedat, two neighbouring Palestinian villages located east of the West Bank (Area C), will be targeted by: 1) Supporting food security and hygiene, through the rehabilitation of a ground water well 2) Supporting the prevention of Covid-19 among farmers 3) Improving resilience and preparedness of communities at risk, by establishing a Community Protection Committee in each of the communities (5 men and 5 women) using the PVCA approach developed with Christian Aid.

title.narrative: Preparedness and Resilience to address impacts of COVID-19, support IDP communities in Kabul

description.narrative:
Outcome 1: Spread of the COVID-19 pandemic is contained, and GBV cases are decreased. Activities: - - Conduct rapid assessment to identify and prioritize vulnerable households. - Conduct community level awareness raising on COVID-19 prevention - Print and distribute nationally approved Risk Communication IEC materials - Conduct digital awareness through radio, TV, banner, poster on COVID-19, stress management, GBV/SGBV. - Conduct sessions on hygiene promotion - Distribution of hygiene kits - Identify and refer vulnerable women who suffer from Mental Health stresses. to mental Health services
Outcome 2: Increased access to food security and livelihood opportunities Activities: - Distribution of standard food packages. - Distribution of special nutrition packages - Conduct "Face Mask Making" training to women - Distribute tailoring/face mask making toolkits
Outcome 3: Increased reflection on critical issues of IDPs in coordination platforms in presence of government and donor communities.
Activities: - Raising IDPs issues especially those in Kabul informal settlements - Recording and sharing case studies.

The COVID-19 Response in Kabul Informal Settlements (KIS) and Place of Origin in Badghis, will be implemented in two IDPs camps/ Informal Settlements in Kabul and 12 villages of Qala-e-Naw and Ab-Kamari districts of Badghis province over a 6 months period (September 1, 2020 to Feb 28, 2021). The intervention will be a multi-sector response covering awareness raising, WASH, food security and livelihood support to mitigate COVID-19 impact on IDPs and vulnerable hard-to-reach communities in Kabul and remote parts of Badghis province. Using integrated, adaptive rapidly scalable approaches leveraging on national and community partner networks, faith/ traditional leaders, youth (prioritizing women and girls), displaced, socially excluded, elderly, people with disabilities and underlying health conditions. Intervention approach fully in line with Grand Bargain commitment of More support and funding tools to local and national responders.

title.narrative: Integrated COVID-19 Response Programme for the Rohingya and Surrounding Host Communities_DAM

description.narrative: Increased access to home-based health care services for the confirmed COVID-19 cases Increased knowledge of health facilities staff and CHW in home-based Covid 19 care Reduced misbeliefs and spread of rumours about Covid 19 in the targeted area Improved hygiene practices to prevent COVID-19 spread in Rohingya Refugee Camp

The main purpose of this project is to provide home-based health care services to COVID-19 confirmed cases and to create awareness among the Rohingya community people to lessen the spread of COVID-19 in the targeted area. In Health, home-based health care services have been designed to prioritize People with Disability, Children, Elderly people and pregnant and lactating women. Health service providers (Doctors & Nurses), Community Health Workers (CHWs) & Volunteers will be provided with capacity building training on COVID-19 Infection, Prevention & Control (IPC) mechanism as well as home-based care. Training will be also provided to faith based religious leaders (Imam) on misbelief and rumours related to COVID-19. Thus, the Imam, considered a trusted source of information, will play vital role in tackling rumours by disseminating approved messaging on Covid-19. CHW and community volunteers will visit households in the targeted areas, identify and referring suspected cases of COVID-19 to laboratory/booth for testing.

description.narrative: Internal allocation from income source to partner Project
Internal allocation from income source to partner Project

Burundi is classified as one of the least prepared countries according the Global Health Security Index (GHS Index) and with forty-two (42) confirmed COVID-19 cases. The Government of Burundi (GoB) has taken some measures such us putting incoming passengers from COVID-19 affected countries into quarantine and closing all borders including the international airport of Bujumbura. Observers from civil society and NGOs believe there are likely many more unreported cases of COVID-19 in the country due to the weakness of the surveillance system at the PoEs and the inefficient quarantine system due to lack of training and preparation of service providers involved as well as limited capacity quarantine spaces. With most of urban and middle class population gradually observing measures issued by the local health authorities in response to the pandemic, vulnerable groups, who are not well equipped to embrace these preventive measures like others due to the lack of information and basic WASH infrastructures, could constitute the hotbed of COVID-19 contamination and spread.

The proposed project will focuses deeply on three of the four objectives raised in the alert: 1. Community-based response through local partnership 2. Advocacy for community-led initiatives 3. Public Health Awareness around COVID-19 The project will strengthen the capacity of 1,100 religious leaders on education and awareness creation from 550 religious congregation in four provinces. Burundi is still having business as usal and the religious leaders, once trained are able to reach their congregation very well. Through this approach, we expect that the 1,100 trained religious leaders will reach additional 35,000 individuals through cascade model. In addition to the religious congregations, the project will work through 60 disaster committees in four provinces most at risk because of the movements of people between the borders, Makamba, Bujumbura, Rutana and Rumonge and 13 interfaith platforms in Bujumbura to reach at least 10,000 people with key preventive messages.

title.narrative: Assistance to vulnerable families affected by Hurricane Eta - Nov 2020

description.narrative: 1) Delivery of food packages: 500 packages will be delivered to the same number of families in order to ensure food for daily consumption (rice, sugar, oil, beans, pasta, oatmeal) while the producers harvest the coffee production that managed to survive the hurricane and obtain some income to supply their basic needs. The content of the food packages has been deisgned in consultation with community members, particularly women, the elderly, and households of various sizes. 2) Delivery of COVID 19 emergency kit: In addition to the damage caused by hurricane ETA, the COVID-19 pandemic is another issue of great importance that needs to be addressed in the coffee growing areas for the current 2020-2021 harvest,

The project responds to a post-Hurricane Epoch food and health security (covid) crisis. These 5000 people are directly affected by the loss of their food and livelihood. The most affected are women, youth and children. There are 16 poor communities and the impact of this project is direct to meeting the immediate needs of these families.

Beneficiaries are able to protect themselves against COVID-19 by adopting appropriate barrier measures. They also adopt human rights respectful behaviour towards migrants returning from the Dominican Republic and people infected with the virus. They are able to work for the good of their community.

This project aims to fight against the spread of the coronavirus in border areas, particularly in the municipality of Lascahobas, through activities to raise awareness among the population in order to encourage them to use barrier measures and adopt responsible and respectful behaviour towards people returning from the Dominican Republic and those infected with the virus. Advocacy activities will be carried out with decision-makers in order to respect the rights of people living in border areas as they are often left to their own devices in the face of the danger that causes the migratory flow in the context of this pandemic. This response has been chosen because migrants and inhabitants of border areas are doubly affected by the impact of this crisis. Firstly, migrants are forced to return home by the context, secondly, traders are the main victims of the cessation of activities in border markets and thirdly, the households that receive their relatives repatriated or returned from the Dominican Republic become more vulnerable.

title.narrative: TJNA - Impact of COVID-19 on Implementation of Economic and Climate Strategies and Plans in Africa

description.narrative: The study will assist in developing CA Africa Just and Green Recovery Advocacy Strategy with key messages touching on climate and economic justice, and support the Africa Division’s economic justice advocacy work in the 10 countries, while at the same time informing regional advocacy, working with our partners. The project will also contribute to CA’s Global COVID-19 Response Strategy, by contributing to the 3Ms as follows: • Minimise the risk of COVID-19 spread to communities: by raising further awareness through increased advocacy informed by research findings on impacts of the disease • Mitigate the poverty and social impacts: by outlining advocacy recommendations that respond to poverty impacts, protecting livelihoods, food insecurity and seek to counter social unrest and violence. • Modify existing humanitarian and development programmes: by preparing African Regional COVID-19 Response strategy that is informed by research findings from the CA countries

This is a timely and novel project aimed at understanding the impact of COVID-19 based on the insights of lived experiences of people in Sub-Saharan Africa countries affected by the Corona Virus Pandemic. Our focus therefore is to collate new evidence and information on impacts of COVID-19 via narratives and stories of the real lived experiences of people, as well as through existing published information, across the 10 CA Africa countries of Nigeria, Kenya, Burkina Faso, Sierra Leone, Malawi, Ethiopia, Burundi, Zimbabwe, Democratic Republic of Congo and South Sudan. The research will be a quick scoping study (of the 10 countries) that will also document current responses by the governments through policies (Recovery strategies, plans) and utilization of funds (tax revenues, loans and grants) and the impact of the pandemic on socio-economic activities, while making use of CA’s Scorecard tool to establish the economic and climate relevance of some on-going government bailouts to corporates, SMEs as well as any cash transfers to the populace.

Burundi is classified as one of the least prepared countries according the Global Health Security Index (GHS Index) and with forty-two (42) confirmed COVID-19 cases. The Government of Burundi (GoB) has taken some measures such us putting incoming passengers from COVID-19 affected countries into quarantine and closing all borders including the international airport of Bujumbura. Observers from civil society and NGOs believe there are likely many more unreported cases of COVID-19 in the country due to the weakness of the surveillance system at the PoEs and the inefficient quarantine system due to lack of training and preparation of service providers involved as well as limited capacity quarantine spaces. With most of urban and middle class population gradually observing measures issued by the local health authorities in response to the pandemic, vulnerable groups, who are not well equipped to embrace these preventive measures like others due to the lack of information and basic WASH infrastructures, could constitute the hotbed of COVID-19 contamination and spread.

The proposed project will focuses deeply on three of the four objectives raised in the alert: 1. Community-based response through local partnership 2. Advocacy for community-led initiatives 3. Public Health Awareness around COVID-19 The project will strengthen the capacity of 1,100 religious leaders on education and awareness creation from 550 religious congregation in four provinces. Burundi is still having business as usal and the religious leaders, once trained are able to reach their congregation very well. Through this approach, we expect that the 1,100 trained religious leaders will reach additional 35,000 individuals through cascade model. In addition to the religious congregations, the project will work through 60 disaster committees in four provinces most at risk because of the movements of people between the borders, Makamba, Bujumbura, Rutana and Rumonge and 13 interfaith platforms in Bujumbura to reach at least 10,000 people with key preventive messages.

title.narrative: Rohingya Crisis Emergency WASH & Health Support project in Ukhiya, Cox’s Bazaar, Bangladesh

description.narrative: Currently, the health post is operating under ACT funded humanitarian response BGD-191 from January 2020 and will be continued till 30th November 2020. Prior to January 2020, this health post was supported by DEC Appeal. Due to funding shortage, it’s vital at this stage to secure resources and support from donors to continue the health post especially considering the gaps to tackle COVID-19 pandemic. CAID is proposing to continue the health post for the period of December 2020 to January 2021 through PWRDF support under the umbrella of ACT Appeal intervention “BGD-191”.

With the global COVID-19 pandemic sweeping Bangladesh, helpless host and Rohingya communities are at an extremely high risk of COVID-19, local response as prevention and treatment resources are scarce. Continuation of health services is required to build community awareness and knowledge of infectious disease preventative measures and practices relevant to the COVID-19 response and to strengthen existing health post to withstand the increased number of patients and strengthen referral. Increased community knowledge is key to preventing the spread of the disease and flattening the infection rate curve to minimize the strain on health services. Simultaneously, Health Posts require enhanced support to access personal protective equipment (PPE) and manage patients seeking care in a manner that minimizes the risk of cross-infection

title.narrative: DEC-Preparedness and Resilience to address impacts of COVID-19, support IDP communities in Badghis

description.narrative:
Outcome 1: Spread of the COVID-19 pandemic is contained, and GBV cases are decreased. Activities: - - Conduct rapid assessment to identify and prioritize vulnerable households. - Conduct community level awareness raising on COVID-19 prevention - Print and distribute nationally approved Risk Communication IEC materials - Conduct digital awareness through radio, TV, banner, poster on COVID-19, stress management, GBV/SGBV. - Conduct sessions on hygiene promotion - Distribution of hygiene kits - Identify and refer vulnerable women who suffer from Mental Health stresses. to mental Health services
Outcome 2: Increased access to food security and livelihood opportunities Activities: - Distribution of standard food packages. - Distribution of special nutrition packages - - Gardening training for 50 people including 25 farmers and 25 women head of households in Badghis - Distribution of fertilizer, vegetable seeds, improved wheat seeds and farm toolkits for 50 farmers in Badghis

The COVID-19 Response in Kabul Informal Settlements (KIS) and Place of Origin in Badghis, will be implemented in two IDPs camps/ Informal Settlements in Kabul and 12 villages of Qala-e-Naw and Ab-Kamari districts of Badghis province over a 6 months period (Feb 2021-Jul 2021). The intervention will be a multi-sector response covering awareness raising, WASH, food security and livelihood support to mitigate COVID-19 impact on IDPs and vulnerable hard-to-reach communities in Kabul and remote parts of Badghis province. Using integrated, adaptive rapidly scalable approaches leveraging on national and community partner networks, faith/ traditional leaders, youth (prioritizing women and girls), displaced, socially excluded, elderly, people with disabilities and underlying health conditions. Intervention approach fully in line with Grand Bargain commitment of More support and funding tools to local and national responders.

title.narrative: SAID - Strengthening acess to rights and social security programmes to the poor and marginalised

description.narrative: The project focuses on facilitating non-discriminatory access to rights, entitlements, social and financial protection measures of the state by the already vulnerable and marginalised owing to a variety of factors which the Covid 19 pandemic and its resultant effect has only accentuated and deepened. More specifically the proposed project would primarily focus following aspects; - Create constant awareness and messaging around health, hygiene, sanitation and preventive behaviours along with entitlement and relief access - Strengthen the agency of the vulnerable and marginalized people and facilitate linkages to various social and financial security schemes and measures, rights, entitlements and relief measures - Facilitation for access to job through the National Rural Employment Guarantee Act which ensures 100 days of work

The project would result in making the proposed marginalised communities more resilient with enhanced information to deal with Covid 19 and improved access to social and financial protection entitlements and benefits from the state. The process of implementation of the project is envisaged to vitally engage the local governance mechanism and functionaries who are responsible for delivery of these entitlements and benefits. These engagements are likely to have a longer-term effect and move towards the construct of better resilience and space for the excluded communities targeted by the project. While the proposed work will be carried out with all the targeted population, owing to the short duration of the project specific results will be limited during the project period and would continue to gain benefits beyond the project period.

title.narrative: To provide marginalised community with immediate health care & food and cash support

description.narrative: Access to healthcare facilities are constrained in Jharkhand owing to its backwardness and difficult topography. The State also has a high number of migrants returning from the cities posing a risk of bringing back the infection with them. There are many vulnerable and poor households stuck in migrant destinations like Delhi NCR with little or no security around food and other basic materials The significant change the project is likely to bring are as follows: a) Communities, including returning migrants, will have easy access to identification, primary care and referral in case of COVID 19 symptoms and infection and there is a reduction in spread of COVID; b) There is an increased uptake of COVID 19 vaccination c) Community systems including the response from local governance functionaries are more coordinated and in time d) Cash transfer to families bring immediate sustenance and relief 500 HH and 250 HH in Delhi NCR

The intervention is based in 3 districts of Jharkhand (Gumla, Simdega and Palamu) where the spread of Covid infection is more. Migrant issue is also enormous in this State. Intervention to focus on a) to establish 30 covid care centres in 30 villages of 3 districts covering 150 hamlets b) Around 10,000 symptomatic people likely to be identified through surveillance across 150 hamlets c) Approximately 3000 migrants returning to village to be kept in isolation centres and treated, if required d) Approximately 1000 serious cases to be referred to bigger hospitals for treatment e) Awareness on Covid appropriate behaviour and vaccination to be given to 15000 individuals f) 500 migrants to receive unconditional cash transfer of 5000/- in their bank account g) 500 HH to receive sanitary hygiene kits and apart from Jharkhand Phia to distribute dry ration and hygiene kits to 500 HH in Delhi/NCR region through volunteers.

Enhancing minimum handwashing hygiene standards. 2 – Access to basic non-Covid related health services by vulnerable group is sustained. 3- Food Security of vulnerable households safeguarded from economic impact due to containment measures.

Ob1-A1-Community level awareness raising through Posters, Public announcements, religious actors, radio-TV messages, mass-SMS to prevent and control COVID-19 and decrease VAWG (M1-5). 2-WASH Support: hygiene kits (WASH cluster standards) and hygiene promotion. (M2-4) 1000 HH. 3- Engage faith leaders, key influencers, health workers, youth & existing community structures for awareness raising on infection prevention and control (M2-5) Ob2 A4- Access to healthcare and psychosocial support: Psychosocial support and counselling to the families of infected people as well as referral service to patients with suspected infection through Community Youth Volunteer Groups. (M1-5)
Ob3, A5- Need assessment: Conduct detailed assessment in targeted communities, IDP camps and Urban areas to identify the most vulnerable people. (M1). A6- Nutrition Support: Distribution infant food packs, malnourished children u-7, pregnant lactating mothers. (M2-4). A7- Social protection and safety-net approaches: Distribution of standard food package: - Wheat Flour, Local Rice, Vegetable Oil, Pulses, Salt, Sugar, (Total cost 86 USD + -10%). This will be especially for 1) extremely poor, 3) disabled, 4) aged, 5) single women headed households (M2-4)

title.narrative: Response to IDP in Suro Berguda woreda in West Guji Zone, Ethiopia

description.narrative: The primary change anticipated is protection of conflict affected and displaced persons comprising of children, women, older people, from risks resulting from unfavourable climate induced hazards such as exposure to rains, poor health and sanitation, insecurity, etc.

The project will undertake 1) distribution of ES/NFI 2) respond to COVID 19 pandemic Detail activities will entail: - Establishing project Committee drawn from Government, host and IDP community, and implementing partner - Identification/selection, verification and validation of eligible beneficiaries - Purchase and transportation of consigned ES/NFI to target woreda - Market assessment will be conducted. The project will purchase 2,134 plastic sheets, 1,067 ropes, 2,134 blankets, 2,134 bed mats, 1,067 mosquito nets, 1,067 kettles (aluminium), 2,134 plates, 4,268 cups, 1067 cooking pots, 1067 ladles, 1,067 washing basin, 1,067 jerry canes, 1,067 handwashing jug with basin, 1,067 multipurpose liquid soap, and 3021 soaps. - Distribution of ESNFI (ES kit, bedding set, kitchen set and mosquito net set) to 1,067 eligible households - Post distribution monitoring following each distribution

description.narrative: Internal allocation from income source to partner Project
Internal allocation from income source to partner Project

Due to the Covid-19 pandemic, funding gaps have been identified in reaching vulnerable households that do not fall under current PARC projects, but whose food security or livelihoods are severely impacted by the situation. The project is supported by Irish Aid funding in 2020 and by CA's own Covid funding in 2021. In 2020, the project will reach households with food delivered to their door. The food will be sourced from small-scale farmers and cooperatives to increase their income and support them through the pandemic. In 2021, the project supports female farmers to upgrade/improve their backyard gardens with mini greenhouses installed. Additionally, PARC staff and Community Protection Committees receive training in remote working, which is likely to continue.

PARC conducted a Rapid Needs Assessment on the agricultural sector, assessing the impact on farmers and small-scale producers. PARC has also continued addressing the needs of food insecure households, who now have further difficulty accessing fresh food and produce, due to their limited availability, markets being shut, loss of income as well as the guidance on physical distancing limiting movement outside of the home. The project not only meets basic needs, but helps support farmers and cooperatives to be able to feed Gaza in the longer term. The female farmers were identified in need in early 2021, following previous support to them from PARC and needs assessments and FGDs. The installation of the greenhouses will enable them to grow food throughout the year, increasing their HHs' food security as well as support the local community.
